arm_group.description: Male participants, type1 diabetic with diabetic neuropathy
Male participants, type1 diabetic without diabetic neuropathy
Male participants, control group non diabetic

brief_summary.textblock:
The aim of the study is to examine the suitability to detect diabetic neuropathy using NIR
      and impedance.

clinical_study.brief_title: NIR- and Multifrequent Impedance Spectroscopy on the Skin in Type 1 Diabetes

detailed_description.textblock:
The aim of the study is to examine how suitable a hand-held measuring probe (DDD-probe)
      using NIR (near infrared light) as well as impedance (conductivity), is to detect early
      signs of diabetic neuropathy.

      The DDD-probe is put directly on the skin and is measuring by the use of light and
      impedance.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  men with type 1 diabetes (WHO criteria)

          -  age 35-50 years

          -  duration of diabetes > 10 years

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  P-creatinine> 120 micromol/l

          -  other acute or chronic disease, or type of treatment that makes the patient
             unsuitable to participate, valuated by the investigator

          -  non intact skin on the measuring spots

          -  the patient is unable to understand the informed consent

study_pop.textblock:
Control group men without diabetes Type1 diabetic men without neuropathy complications
        Type 1 diabetic men with neuropathy complications

clinical_study.official_title: NIR (Near Infrared)- Spectroscopy and Multifrequent Impedance Spectroscopy on the Skin to Detection of Sensory and Autonomic Neuropathy Among Patients With Type 1 Diabetes

authority: Denmark: The Danish National Committee on Biomedical Research Ethics

primary_outcome.description: Near infrared (NIR) is measured by spectroscopy on the skin using the DDD probe

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Cross-Sectional
